Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Does the concept of a/an K-homomorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois group of a Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To determine whether the concept of a K-homomorphism is necessary for defining the Galois group of a field extension, we need to analyze the definitions provided:

1. The Galois group \(\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)\) is defined as the group of all field automorphisms of \(L\) that fix every element of \(K\). This means each element of the Galois group is a map from \(L\) to itself (an automorphism) that acts as the identity on \(K\).

2. A K-homomorphism is defined as a field homomorphism \(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\) between two field extensions \(L / K\) and \(L' / K\) that also acts as the identity on \(K\).

From these definitions, we see that the concept of a K-homomorphism generalizes the idea of a map between two different field extensions that both contain \(K\) and respects the structure of \(K\) by fixing its elements. However, the definition of the Galois group specifically involves automorphisms (i.e., isomorphisms from a field to itself) that fix \(K\), not necessarily mappings between different fields.

Thus, while the concept of a K-homomorphism includes the necessary condition of fixing \(K\), it is broader than needed for defining the Galois group, which only requires automorphisms of a single field \(L\). Therefore, the concept of a K-homomorphism is not necessary for the definition of the Galois group of a field extension, as the latter can be fully defined using only the notion of field automorphisms that fix \(K\).
